Nicely articulated. I would argue that you are correct on both counts: the conventions are a reflection of who we are and a gathering of what is largely a subculture of people active in politics.

Politicians are like actors: they need talent, drive, and public support to be successful. The public ultimately decides who succeeds based upon the conduct we are willing to tolerate in order to benefit from their talents. And no one reaches the top without enormous ambition. No Mr. Smith goes to Washington. Lincoln was deeply involved in directing his surrogates to cut the deals necessary to assure his nomination. I'm sure that Washington was active in his own selection as president.

Like actors, politicians are supported by people and organizations with a vital interest in their success. These circles do whatever it takes to ensure public support for their champion. A hundred years ago, it was pamphlets and payoffs to whoever could deliver the votes. Today, it's pretty much the same except the pamphlets have evolved into expensive, sophisticated media campaigns and the payoffs are promises to those who can finance them.

Yet the goal is always the same: to win over enough public support. We have always been aware of and tolerated varying degrees of sliminess. So, yes, most of us don't go into politics, but we acquiesce in the system. It's our choice and says something about who we are.

Nothing prevents us from pushing for change except the will to make the effort.

I wonder if these conventions were an accurate reflection of who and what we are as a nation. Our reps on display, our work as voters fully realized and materialized on a fantastic stage for all to see. Right? Or, are these conventions only a showcase of those people who somehow never lost their desire to pursue a career in a profession many of us grew to loath?

If that's the case, then we have what amounts to a sub-culture representing the nation; a sub-culture of those who didn't turn their backs on politics, but instead somehow navigated through the morass of negativity that justifiably surrounds it. One wonders what type of individual thrives off of what the rest of us cringe over. I wonder if this is the reason we can never seem to relate to the circus that has become American politics.

Sometimes, though, some of the best and brightest do manage to trickle through the rigors of our condemnation and harsh assessment, undeterred, and free to risk his/her neck in an unforgiving and less than sophisticated public arena. But most of those who 'trickle through' as of late, it seems, are not those we can be particularly proud of. For me, these conventions illustrated that more than ever.

Unlike in the past, I had little interest in watching. I felt that they had lost much of their luster. Maybe their magnitude has been diminished by the digital age -- lost in a pool of choices. But maybe it's more simple. Maybe there are just fewer of those who we look forward to seeing.

I agree with Mr. Tough that character matters-- I would probably use the phrase "life skills". The older I get, the more I think that persistence, resilience, optimism and interpersonal skills are key determinants of success. Talent, education and technical skills matter, too, especially at the start of one's career, but "life skills" grow increasingly important as one advances up the latter.

And "life skills" are especially important when things go wrong or one fails or stumbles, which happens to us all. Adversity and failure afflict everyone: the important thing is learning how to pick yourself up and move on.

Susan,

Of course you're right that no one should "give up" and plenty can be done, but at this point in the game we must look carefully at what should be done.

Recent events in the Arctic have established, to my mind at least, that we've passed a major tipping point in climate change. There is no going back, and a good case can be made that methane releases from the Siberian continental shelf and permafrost could trigger runaway global warming.

Geoengineering of the Arctic atmosphere is not a realistic option. For one thing, it probably won't work, given the instability of the jet stream and the fact that nobody knows how to go about influencing the climate on that scale. For another, the Russians, who love the fact that the Arctic sea is becoming ice free, won't stand for it.

Add in the fact that it is extremely unlikely that we will significantly cut greenhouse gas emissions in the needed time frame of, say, ten years, and … sigh…I think we can figure that we're in for pretty big changes.

What to do next, aside from looking squarely at these realities and letting them soak in, is unclear. But we have limited resources, and we need to use them wisely if we want to survive the coming debacle.

I agree. As a 60 year-old Democrat, I'm very loathe to depend on the social media-savvy younger voters to actually turn out at an election site and vote. I can truthfully say that certain of the social-media generation I am quite familiar with (or family with, more accurately) are more likely to use their "flying fingers" to tweet or Facebook a message than they are to engage in any sort of actual face-to-face contact, and that worries me as far as their actually rather than virtually participating in the voting process. The real revolution for these younger social-media types will come when they can actually vote using their smart phones, by app or text, and not having to be inconvenienced by an actual appearance at a voting place.

Oh, I'm getting old...

"The Democrats simply have to turn buzz into ballots."

Unfortunately, that's not so easy. Historically, voters in their teens and early 20s have turned out less regularly than older voters.

With respect to the Democrats' heavier use of online tools and social media: Makes sense, as the have the edge among younger voters. Understandable that the Republicans are less heavily engaged given that their partisans are more likely to be older. While the social media are useful, the real issue is who shows up and votes on November 6.
And that should be 'up the ladder' (not 'latter'.)   So much for technical skills.

You have missed the whole point about how significant our internal consumption of GDP is while how minor the impact of foreign investment and balance of payments actually are. Boosting demand impacts overwhelmingly domestically.

The success of my business, and every other business on my street, depends on having THOUSANDS of middle class customers who are paid well enough that they have a little money left over at the end of the month to spend at places like ours.

If enough customers like what I offer, AND they can afford it, I hire more workers to meet the increased demand. Then they can spend some of their new income at places like the restaurant across the street.

If enough customers like the restaurant across the street, then THEY hire more workers and some of these new workers might become MY customers.

As my business grows, I increase my orders to my vendors. When enough businesses like mine increase our orders then the vendor hires more workers and orders more from the factory. As the factory's orders increase, they hire more workers and pass the increased profits up to their shareholders.

That's Demand-side Economics -- bottom-up economics in the REAL WORLD.

To get the economy moving in the short term we need to put more people to work so they can start spending again on more than just necessities.

In the long term, we need to strengthen the middle class by reversing 30 years of Supply-side policies that redistribute wealth -- upwards. And we need to reexamine our trade policies and start telling countries that want to sell goods in the U.S. that they will face the same restrictions that American companies face when trying to sell goods in their country.

The US had an import deficit is from $500 billion in 2010 to $558 billion in 2011.
What is the point of raising demand, when a significant part of this raise goes to outsourced slave worker plants of US and chinese tycoons ?
I think for keynes you must take all economic protagonists into account, and than you will see, that US is already the big demand-side, while the BRIC is just production.
Beside the trade deficit to much money get lost in artificial trade in the financial sector.

I think the vast majority of homeschooling choices are based on religious beliefs. The "37 percent higher than public school scores" statistics are from a report put together by a homeschooling advocate organization, and are to some extent based on home-administered tests with results self-reported to the study. Many people send the tests to Bob Jones University for scoring.

I don't think that homeschooling is wrong. The author of this blog post seems highly intelligent. Her intentions seem to be both secular and in the best interests of her kids. And I think parents have the right (up to a point) to determine what's best for their kids. But I'm always wary of statistics like those presented. And I'm wary of the reasoning behind denying a child opportunities for social interaction. If you live in a particularly bad school district, or if there are documented cases of violence or bullying, I see the point. But if it's really about keeping kids away from others who aren't like them, I'd think twice.
